docs.title: ✨ Magic Text: UI Click
docs.text: Provides access to the text that was clicked in the UI.

docs.title: {ui_click_text}
docs.text:
Returns: The text of the clicked UI element. Useful when the clicked text may vary, such as dynamic content or when using regular expressions. Example: If the clicked button says Confirm, the result will be Confirm.

Requires: The macro must include the UI Click trigger.

docs.title: ✨ Magic Text: USB Device Connected
docs.text: These magic text values are available when a USB device is connected.

docs.title: {usb_product_name}
docs.text: Returns: The name of the connected USB device. Example: SanDisk Ultra USB 3.0

docs.title: {usb_manufacturer_name}
docs.text: Returns: The manufacturer of the connected USB device. Example: SanDisk

docs.title: {usb_device_hash}
docs.text:
Returns: A unique identifier (hash code) generated for the connected USB device. Useful for identifying and differentiating USB devices. Note: This hash may vary depending on the port or device state.

Requires: The macro must include the USB Device Connected/Disconnected trigger.

docs.title: ✨ Magic Text: Weather
docs.text:
Magic Text: {weather_temperature_c} Returns: Current temperature in degrees Celsius. Example: Returns 22 if the temperature is 22°C Simple explanation: Shows the current temperature in °C.

Magic Text: {weather_temperature_fahrenheit} Returns: Current temperature in degrees Fahrenheit. Example: Returns 71.6 if the temperature is 71.6°F Simple explanation: Shows the current temperature in °F.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_speed} Returns: Current wind speed in meters per second (m/s). Example: Returns 3.5 if wind speed is 3.5 m/s Simple explanation: Shows how fast the wind is blowing in m/s.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_speed_mph} Returns: Current wind speed in miles per hour (mph). Example: Returns 7.8 if wind speed is 7.8 mph Simple explanation: Wind speed shown in mph.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_speed_kmh} Returns: Current wind speed in kilometers per hour (km/h). Example: Returns 12.6 if wind speed is 12.6 km/h Simple explanation: Wind speed shown in km/h.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_direction} Returns: Wind direction in degrees (0–360). Example: Returns 270 if the wind is coming from the west Simple explanation: Shows wind direction as an angle (e.g., 90 = east).

Magic Text: {weather_humidity} Returns: Current humidity percentage. Example: Returns 60 if the humidity is 60% Simple explanation: Shows how humid the air is right now.

Magic Text: {weather_conditions} Returns: Text description of the current weather conditions (e.g., "clear sky", "rain", "overcast"). Example: Returns clear sky Simple explanation: Describes the weather in plain words.

Requires: You must use the Weather trigger before accessing these Magic Texts.

docs.title: ⏱️ Stopwatches in MacroDroid
docs.text: Stopwatches allow you to measure elapsed time inside your macros — perfect for tracking durations, delays, or custom time-based logic.

docs.title: 📍 Where to Find Stopwatches
docs.text:
You can access and manage stopwatches from the Stopwatch tile on the main screen of MacroDroid. From there, you can:

  • ➕ Create new stopwatches
  • ✏️ Rename existing stopwatches
  • 🗑️ Delete stopwatches you no longer need
  • ▶️ Start/Stop any stopwatch manually

📺 Video Tutorial: Watch the official MacroDroid stopwatch guide here: 👉 MacroDroid Stopwatch YouTube Video

docs.title: 🧩 Using Stopwatches in Macros
docs.text: Stopwatches can be integrated into different parts of your macros:

docs.title: 🔫 Trigger
docs.text: Trigger a macro based on stopwatch conditions 👉 Introduction to triggers 👉 Stopwatch trigger

docs.title: 🎬 Action
docs.text: Start, stop, reset, or get the current time from a stopwatch 👉 Introduction to actions 👉 Stopwatch action

docs.title: 🚧 Constraint/Condition
docs.text: Run actions only if a stopwatch has passed or not passed a set duration 👉 Introduction to constraints 👉 Stopwatch constraint

docs.title: ✨ Magic Text
docs.text: Use stopwatch values dynamically in text fields (e.g., notifications, logs) 👉 Magic text introduction 👉 Magic text stopwatch

docs.title: 🛠️ Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Measure how long since an event happened
  • Delay actions until a stopwatch exceeds a time
  • Reset time after specific conditions
  • Log or display how much time passed between two points

Think of stopwatches as custom timers you control — start them when something begins, stop them when it ends, and use that info to make smart decisions inside your macros.

docs.title: 🚀 Introduction to Triggers in MacroDroid
docs.text:
Triggers in MacroDroid are instantaneous events that your device detects to start a macro. They are the spark that initiates your automation, telling MacroDroid when to execute the macro’s actions. From detecting a screen unlock to receiving a notification, triggers allow you to create responsive and dynamic automations tailored to your needs.

Go to trigger list

docs.title: 🔹 What Are Triggers?
docs.text: A trigger is an event that your device can detect, such as a change in battery level, a specific time, or a location update. For a macro to be valid, it must include at least one trigger. The macro must also be enabled (not disabled) at the exact moment the trigger event occurs for it to fire.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text: A trigger like "Charger Connected" can start a macro that runs actions such as "Turn On Wi-Fi" or "Show Notification" when you plug in your device.

docs.title: 🔹 Using Multiple Triggers
docs.text: You can add multiple triggers to a single macro. If any one of these triggers fires, the macro will execute, assuming all constraints (if any) are met. This provides flexibility to start a macro from different events.

docs.title: Important Note:
docs.text: Triggers cannot be combined with AND logic (e.g., "Trigger 1 AND Trigger 2") using a "Trigger Fired" constraint because triggers are instantaneous events. It’s highly improbable for two events to occur at exactly the same time. When a macro runs, it is always initiated by exactly one trigger.

docs.title: Alternative to AND Logic:
docs.text: Instead of combining triggers with AND, you can add constraints to individual triggers to limit when they fire based on other conditions. For example, you can add a "Time of Day" constraint to a "Screen On" trigger to ensure it only activates during specific hours.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text: A macro with two triggers—"Charger Connected" and "Headphones Connected"—will run its actions if either event occurs. To make a trigger like "Charger Connected" only fire during the day, add a constraint like "Time of Day: 8:00 AM - 10:00 PM" to that specific trigger.

docs.title: 🔹 Common Trigger Examples
docs.text: MacroDroid offers a wide variety of triggers to suit different automation needs. Some popular examples include: - Device Events: "Screen On/Off," "Charger Connected/Disconnected," or "Battery Level Drops." - Time-Based: "Regular Interval" (e.g., every hour) or "Specific Time." - Connectivity: "Wi-Fi Connected/Disconnected" or "Bluetooth Device Connected." - Notifications: "Notification Received" from a specific app. - Location: "Enter/Exit Location" based on GPS or network data.

docs.title: 🔹 Why Are Triggers Important?
docs.text:
• Initiation: Triggers are the starting point of every macro, determining when your automation runs.
  • Flexibility: With multiple triggers, you can make a single macro respond to various events.
  • Precision: Adding constraints to triggers allows you to fine-tune when they activate, ensuring your macros run only in the right context.

docs.title: Practical Example:
docs.text:
A macro designed to save battery might include: - Trigger: "Battery Level Drops Below 20%" to detect low battery. - Additional Trigger: "Screen On" to catch when the device is actively used. - Constraint (on the "Screen On" trigger): "Not Charging" to ensure the macro only runs when the device isn’t plugged in. - Actions: "Lower Brightness" and "Show Notification: Low Battery!"

Triggers are the foundation of MacroDroid’s automations, giving you control over when your macros run. Whether you’re creating simple automations or complex workflows with multiple triggers and constraints, experimenting with triggers will help you unlock the full power of MacroDroid!

docs.title: 📍 Trigger: Geofence (location)
docs.text:
Geofence triggers automatically start your macros when your device enters or exits a defined geographical area. They provide battery-efficient location detection using Google Play Services.

docs.text:

docs.text: • Trigger if previous location unknown: When enabled, the trigger will activate even if the device's previous location wasn't known. Useful for: Ensuring triggers fire after device reboot or when location services were temporarily disabled.

docs.title: 🧠 Understanding Variables in MacroDroid
docs.text: Variables are used to store and manipulate data in your macros — they’re like containers that hold values your macros can use and modify as they run.

docs.title: 🔄 Types of Variables
docs.text: MacroDroid supports two main types of variables:

docs.title: 🌐 Global Variables
docs.text:
• Syntax: {v=varName} or [v=varName]
  • Scope: Available in all macros, including Action Blocks
  • Ideal for sharing data between different macros or across multiple triggers

docs.title: 📦 Local Variables
docs.text:
• Syntax: {lv=varName} or [lv=varName]
  • Scope: Only available within the macro where they were created (including Action Blocks called by that macro)
  • Ideal for temporary or macro-specific values

Use Global Variables when you need persistent or shared data. Use Local Variables for isolated, one-time-use values within a single macro execution.

docs.title: 🧰 Supported Variable Types
docs.text:
You can create variables using different data types depending on your needs:

  • String – Text (e.g. "Hello world")
  • Integer – Whole numbers (e.g. 5, -12)
  • Decimal – Numbers with decimals (e.g. 3.14, -0.01)
  • Boolean – True/False
  • Array – A list of values (e.g. [1, 2, 3] or ["A", "B", "C"])
  • Dictionary – A collection of key-value pairs (e.g. {"name": "Alex", "age": 30})

These types allow for powerful data handling inside your macros.

docs.title: 🔒 Secure Variables
docs.text:
When creating a variable, you can choose to mark it as Secure.

A variable marked as secure will have its contents cleared when macro(s) are shared/exported or uploaded to the template store.

This is useful when your variable holds sensitive information like passwords, tokens, or personal data that shouldn’t be shared.

docs.title: ⚙️ Variables in Conditions and Constraints
docs.text:
Variables can be used in:

  • Conditions (e.g., “if isLoggedIn is true”)
  • Constraints (e.g., “run only if batteryLevel > 50”)
  • Text fields by referencing {v=yourVar} or {lv=yourVar}
  • Magic Text inputs across actions

They let you dynamically control the behavior of your macros based on real-time values.

docs.title: 💡 Summary
docs.text:
Type Syntax Scope Good For Global {v=varName} All macros and action blocks Shared or persistent data Local {lv=varName} Single macro and its blocks Temporary or isolated values Secure (any variable) Same as global/local Hiding sensitive data in exports

Variables are the brain of your macro logic. Master them and you’ll unlock the full power of MacroDroid 🚀
